Hearing.Statement: <opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. JOHN SHIMKUS, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF ILLINOIS</opening> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">Welcome to our hearing this morning as we examine the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's fiscal year 2019 budget proposal. The NRC's essential role in licensing and regulating nuclear facilities is of great importance to my Illinois constituents.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">Illinois produces the largest share of nuclear-generated electricity in the country. Throughout the State, the commercial nuclear energy industry supports thousands of high- paying jobs, funds local school districts, and provides reliable, clean, baseload electricity around the clock.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">In fact, a little over 75 years ago, Illinois was the site, at a lab under the University of Chicago's football field, where physicists and engineers first generated a self- sustaining nuclear chain reaction. We are proud to be the birthplace of nuclear technology.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">While I do not have any commercial nuclear power plants in my southern Illinois district, I do represent the Nation's only uranium conversion facility, located in Metropolis, Illinois.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">In October, the plant's owner announced it was suspending operations at the site due to market conditions for uranium. We have a glut of uranium on the market and lingering low demand, in part due to the suspension of the Japanese fleet of nuclear power plants in the wake of the Fukushima earthquake, or tsunami, 7 years ago.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">While there may not be an immediate fix to the uranium market, the most important policy to help my constituents return to work is a strong, positive outlook for our Nation's domestic nuclear industry.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">To maintain a robust nuclear industry, Congress must consider the many different opportunities to provide a pathway to keep existing plants operational, while establishing the foundation for new nuclear energy deployment in the next decade.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">While mining, converting, enriching, and manufacturing nuclear fuel is a necessity to support the front end of the fuel cycle, we are long past due to manage the back end of the fuel cycle.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">As we do this, we have to recognize the uncertainty about our used fuel commitments will continue to be a political albatross around nuclear energy development until the Department of Energy starts sending clear signals and reconstitutes its nuclear waste management organization.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">I very much appreciate that last year the Commission, for the first time since 2010, requested funding to resume its review of the pending Yucca Mountain license application, as required by law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">While it is still incumbent on Congress to provide the funding, it is refreshing to see an administration that is committed to following the law.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">As I have noted on many occasions, the NRC's independent review of the license will answer the safety and environmental impact questions the State of Nevada has raised.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">To gain the public's confidence in nuclear energy, we must have a functioning nuclear waste management program. The Commission's strong legacy of effective and efficient regulation is another key component of public confidence.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">However, the many pressures on the nuclear industry provide an opportunity for the NRC to reassess its regulatory process and flexibility.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">The Commission's fiscal year 2019 budget sets the parameters for how the organization will steward its resources in a changing environment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">Last month, we heard a clear message of urgency. As your former colleague, Bill Ostendorff, succinctly pointed out, our civilian nuclear energy industry infrastructure is the underpinning of our strategic nuclear defense capabilities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">In fact, I went down and visited with Admiral Caldwell just last week, and it was a great visit and I would encourage a lot of my colleagues to do that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">In turn, an agile regulatory regime that oversees the breadth of the nuclear supply capacity supports our national interests.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="HON. JOHN SHIMKUS">Mr. Ostendorff's testimony highlighted the critical need to advance a suite of nuclear policies to define our nuclear future and establish a durable program to sustain the industry for the next generation of nuclear leaders.</paragraph>

Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">In my home State of Tennessee, TVA is leading the way with three nuclear plants and seven units capable of generating an average of 7,800 megawatts of electricity each day.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Watts Bar, and I know you all are familiar with Watts Bar-- that's near the northern end of Chickamauga Reservoir in east Tennessee--is the first new nuclear reactor built in the 21st century and supplies enough electricity for about 1.2 million households in the Tennessee Valley.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Watts Bar experienced its fair share of challenges and setbacks in the process to becoming operational. Unfortunately, we are seeing those challenges across the country, and without a reasonable, modern, flexible regulatory system, the U.S. will continue to struggle to maintain existing plants, leaving little opportunity for new plants to come online.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">So it is essential that the NRC develop a more agile and responsive regulatory model equipped for today's changing energy industry and security needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Shimkus"> And I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Shimkus</speaker> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Shimkus">Gentlelady yields back the time.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. PAUL TONKO, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF NEW YORK</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. PAUL TONKO"> Chair now recognizes the ranking member of the subcommittee, Mr. Tonko, for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Tonko</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you, and good morning.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Thank you to both Chair Shimkus and Chair Upton for holding this hearing, and welcome back and thank you to our Chair Svinicki and Commissioner Burns for appearing before the subcommittees today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Tonko">And let me extend a special welcome back to Commissioner Baran, who served with distinction as a professional staff member of this committee for a great number of years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Tonko">So welcome to all of you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Tonko">The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's mission is to license and regulate the Nation's civilian use of radioactive materials to ensure adequate protection of public health and safety, to promote the common defense and security, and to protect the environment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Tonko">This deed is no easy task, and I want to put an additional emphasis on protecting health and safety.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Members on this committee have a range of views on existing and new nuclear power, but I believe there is unanimous agreement that we need high standards for nuclear safety.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Tonko">So thank you to the Commission staff that have this awesome responsibility. We are here today to discuss the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's fiscal year 2019 budget request of $970.7 million.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Tonko">This represents an increase of about $60 million compared to the fiscal year '18 annualized continuing resolution level.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Much of this increase is being driven by the $47.7 million for activities related to the disposal of spent nuclear fuel and high-level radioactive waste.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Licensing activities related to the proposed Yucca Mountain Repository, which I am sure my colleague, Mr. Shimkus, was happy to see, are included in the request.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I would also note the budget request represents a decrease of 149 FTEs compared to the fiscal year 2018 annualized continuing resolution, with 123 of those FTEs coming from the Nuclear Reactor Safety Program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Over the past few years, Commissioners have appeared before this committee and provided updates on Project Aim, the Commission's effort to right size the agency in light of changes and trends occurring in the nuclear industry.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Tonko">Without a doubt, the Commission has been streamlined. The budget has been reduced by about 13 percent and staff by over 500 FTEs since 2014. This has been a steady trend.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Tonko">While I understand and appreciate the goals of making the Commission more efficient, continuing cuts at this pace is not a good way for such an important and technical agency to run.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Tonko">At some point, you are no longer capable of doing more with less. You just end up doing less, and safety is one place where doing less is nonnegotiable.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Tonko">So I would caution against continuing to push reduction targets if we are approaching a point where critical Commission functions such as safety inspection hours begin to suffer because, if the Commission is unable to maintain essential personnel or replenish its aging workforce or hire additional staff with expertise in new technologies, it could be the public that does suffer.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Tonko">And the industry will certainly suffer too with delays in licensing and review processes. The Commission must be staffed and resourced at levels appropriate for carrying out its critical oversight and safety missions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I also wanted to mention that we have spent quite a bit of time this past year discussing grid resilience, and Secretary Perry's notice of proposed rulemaking to FERC, which would have compensated power generators with 90 days of fuel on site, was rightly rejected, in my opinion.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Tonko">I know there are many Members that believe the nuclear industry is at a competitive disadvantage and nuclear energy production should be fairly compensated for its positive attributes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Tonko">We may disagree which of those attributes are most important.
